I couldn't agree more. The Times has made it so easy to bash Millennials by focusing on a handful of very wealthy young people who are trying to enter glamorous, high-profile industries. Nobody, but nobody, is going to have sympathy for a trust-funder who is sad because he can't break into film production. Why not instead look at why you need three years of Raiser's Edge experience to get a $20,000, entry-level data-entry job in nonprofits? Why operating a front-desk switchboard or pushing the mail cart is now considered a job for a college graduate? Why you need to return to school for two more years on top of a BA to get a $24,000 job entering medical codes into a computer in a cubicle farm?

The kind and intensity of pain discussed here is far worse than that of osteoarthritis. I ought to know--it was OA induced by injuries that led me to get my knees replaced; and post-op pain dwarfs that of OA. (After a year, post-op pain fades to where it's much less than OA pain--but that's quite a long while, the first few months of which can be unbearable without STRONG pain relief beyond what an NSAID or OTC painkiller can provide). If you were able to "bear the pain for about a year," and these folk remedies gave you relief, that speaks volumes. As to Celebrex, an OTC NSAID such as naproxen would have been cheaper & worked much better. Granted, it's tougher on the gut than Celebrex but much more effective.

You may have done just as serious damage to your gut by taking that much ginger in pill form. (Supplements are never as safe or effective as "nutrients on the hoof"). Moreover, supplements are totally unregulated so one has no idea what his true dosage is--or what else is in that pill that might inhibit or intensify the effect of the ginger (or worse). And as for the topical hydrocortisone? It's doubtful that it caused your pain relief--it's meant to reduce superficial inflammation (and can permanently thin your skin). Any relief you perceived from it and the ginger was probably a combination of the placebo effect unless you used a ton of it--you believed it'd work so it did.

And you gave your MAID's advice more credence than your MD's? OY.

To all you pain suffers, let me tell to you my story.

About 3 years ago, I have developed severe water retention due to my eating out a lot. My knees were in severe pain.

The doctor put me on a water pill and prescribed Celebrex. However, the Celebrex was simply too expensive (my health insurance did not adequately cover it). So, I bore the pain for about a year.

Then after a year my house-maid suggested that I consume ginger on a daily basis. So, I went to GNC and bought ginger pills. I started to take 4 a day.

On the 5th day, the pain in my right knee was totally gone.

However, the pain in my left knee continued for another year. I tried one cream after another. Then, I started to rub hydro-cortisone cream on my left knee. Within several days, the chronic pain went away.

I tell this story in the hopes that these remedies might help someone else.

Though opioid abuse leading to addiction is tragic and real, intractable pain patients have become collateral damage in the "war on drugs." I had two knee replacement surgeries a year apart. After the first, I was prescribed hydrocodone/acetaminophen (Norco) on an as-needed basis both in post-op rehab and once discharged to home. By 3 weeks post-op I was able to cut my dose in half; by 4 weeks by 2/3; by 6 weeks I had transitioned completely to non-presecription analgesics. A year later, I was prescribed the same opioid--but this time, due to pressure on physicians by law enforcement agencies and state medical boards, my dosage in the rehab center was half what it was the year before; as a result my pain returned sooner and was never completely controlled until I returned home and set my own medication and weaning schedule. The upshot was that once I was able to decide what to take and when, I eventually weaned just as completely at six weeks as the year before--but in the first three weeks post-op this time my pain management was grossly inadequate and my physical therapy progressed far more slowly than after the first surgery.

When authorities intimidate doctors into prescribing inadequate pain control, their patients suffer--and are likelier to turn to street drugs for analgesia because their access to legal opioids is restricted. For every addict it's possible there are five pain patients who suffer needlessly. And there is no virtue in needless suffering!

I still think this column isn't bad overall, but I have to second others who scratched their heads in reaction to your bemoaning of political science while praising economics. Over the last few decades, political science has turned into a near de facto subfield of economics. And this is a problem because, at the risk of generalizing and with all due respect to Paul Krugman (who is an exception), people studying economics in academia at the graduate level seem to be very averse to reading words of any kind. They really appear to hate anything that's longer than a 15-page article and not full of mathematical equations. Economists tend to dismiss political scientists as long-winded "storytellers" who write too many books. The creeping "economics-ization" of political science that has resulted has led, in fact, to many of the things you bemoan about political science.

I remember 1979 very well indeed. I had a job offer that took me from California to Arizona right in the middle of the oil embargo. Odd even gas lines caused far more turmoil for the middle class then could ever double digit inflation.

But it wasn't the little guy who devastated economic thinking. It was the holders of mortgage debt and to a lesser extent credit card debt and auto loans. To this day all forms of personal debt interest is from one to three percent higher than it should be. All in anticipation of a return to inflation that Keynesians to this day cannot explain.

Of course if any economist could ever admit that money is not a store of wealth, that it is nothing more than an event that occurs in the imagination, then perhaps all could be explained.

Suppose you run a business. You make cars. You cut lawns. Are you going to hire more people, build more factories, or buy another mower, if you can't sell more cars or cut more lawns? It's true that people want a new car or their lawn cut, but they don't have enough money to pay for the car or the lawn service. Too many are out of work. Too many have low paying jobs.

It's not taxes or regulations that are holding the economy back. It is the lack of money on the part of those who would like to spend it. There are only two sources of money.

1. The Rich have a lot of money. They could afford to pay their workers more, build new factories, hire more people, BUT they are not going to do that until there are people who can buy more stuff.

2. The only other option is the federal government. It can print money. It can spend money. There are many worthwhile ways to do so. It can fix our roads and bridges, build a new power grid, give grants to the states to help with education, sponsor research, etc., etc., etc. Even simply giving money to poor people to buy food gets more money into the economy.

As a percentage of GDP our public debt is about 38% less than it was in 1946. From 1946 to 1973 we increased the debt in dollars by 75%. BUT we had prosperity. Real median household income surged 74%.

After WWI we had 10 years of balanced budget. We decreased the debt in dollars by 40%. This was followed by the worst economy in our history.

In 2004 when the citizens of Lafayette, Louisiana pushed their local utility company to provide high speed internet service the town found itself pressured by Bell South and Cox Communications to pass laws that would prevent that. When that didn't happen Bell and Cox sued, then forced a referendum, the result of which was that they lost. But they'd tied up progress for 3 years.

The city has built a system and despite the cost the result has been that the citizens saved over $5.7 million by 2011 alone.

So, Paul, the answer to your question is straightforward: if people in Lafayette are saving $5.7 million, corporations, and powerful pockets, aren't receiving it.

Chattanooga built what may be the most advanced fiber system in the U.S. but private carriers pressured the state to not pass legislation that would allow Chattanooga to expand the system. Time Warner pressured North Carolina to pass legislation to prevent cities from providing service.

Abba sang about our plight: "Money, Money, Money"

"Money, money, money, always sunny, in the rich man's world."

In December 2013 the NYTs began an article on our plight by pointing out that Austin is our 7th largest city but lags far behind Riga, Latvia in broadband service. The U.S. ranks somewhere north of 30th in the world for communications services.

http://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/30/technology/us-struggling-to-keep-pace-...
